Class SingleChronicleQueue

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.openhft.chronicle.core.io.AbstractCloseable

extends net.openhft.chronicle.core.io.AbstractCloseable

      • refreshDirectoryListing

        public void refreshDirectoryListing()
        Description copied from interface: ChronicleQueue
        Refreshed this ChronicleQueue's view of the directory used for storing files.

        Invoke this method if you delete file from a chronicle-queue directory

        The problem solved by this is that we cache the structure of the queue directory in order to reduce file system adds latency. Calling this method, after deleting .cq4 files, will update the internal caches accordingly,

        Specified by:
        refreshDirectoryListing in interface ChronicleQueue

      • createNewAppenderOnceConditionIsMet

        @NotNull
protected @NotNull ExcerptAppender createNewAppenderOnceConditionIsMet()
        Construct a new ExcerptAppender once the createAppenderCondition is met.

        This should be called by any sub-classes that require an appender but don't want to use the thread-local one that can be acquired via acquireAppender()

        Returns:
        The new appender

      • constructAppender

        @NotNull
protected @NotNull ExcerptAppender constructAppender()
        Construct a new ExcerptAppender.

        This is protected so sub-classes can override the creation of an appender, to create a new appender, sub-classes should call createNewAppenderOnceConditionIsMet()

        Returns:
        The new appender

      • storeFileListener

        protected StoreFileListener storeFileListener()

      • acquireAppender

        @NotNull
public @NotNull ExcerptAppender acquireAppender()
        Description copied from interface: ChronicleQueue
        Returns a ExcerptAppender for this ChronicleQueue that is local to the current Thread.

        An Appender can be used to store new excerpts sequentially to the queue.

        An Appender is NOT thread-safe and, in addition to that, confined to be used by the creating thread only.. Sharing an Appender across threads is unsafe and will inevitably lead to errors and unspecified behaviour.

        This method returns a ThreadLocal appender, so does not produce any garbage, hence it's safe to simply call this method every time an appender is needed.

        Specified by:
        acquireAppender in interface ChronicleQueue
        Returns:
        Returns a ExcerptAppender for this ChronicleQueue that is local to the current Thread

      • queueLock

        @NotNull
public @NotNull QueueLock queueLock()
        Returns:
        the QueueLock This lock is held while the queue replication cluster is back-filling. By Back-filling we mean that, as part of the fail-over process a sink, may actually have more data than a source, hence we need to back copy data from the sinks to the source upon startup. While we are doing this we lock the queue so that new appenders can not be created.

        Queue locks have no impact if you are not using queue replication because the are implemented as a no-op.

      • appendLock

        public WriteLock appendLock()
        Returns:
        the WriteLock that is used to lock appends. This is only used by Queue Enterprise sink replication handlers. See Queue Enterprise docs for more details.

      • createTailer

        @NotNull
public @NotNull ExcerptTailer createTailer(String id)
        Description copied from interface: ChronicleQueue
        Creates and returns a new ExcerptTailer for this ChronicleQueue with the given unique id.

        The id is used to persistently store the latest index for the Tailer. Any new Tailer with a previously used id will continue where the old one left off. A Tailer is NOT thread-safe. A Tailer can be created by one Thread and might be used by at most one other Thread.. Sharing a Tailer across threads is unsafe and will inevitably lead to errors and unspecified behaviour.

        If the provided id is null, the Tailer will be unnamed and this is equivalent to invoking ChronicleQueue.createTailer().

        Specified by:
        createTailer in interface ChronicleQueue
        Parameters:
        id - unique id for a tailer which uses to track where it was up to
        Returns:
        a new ExcerptTailer for this ChronicleQueue with the given unique id
        See Also:
        ChronicleQueue.createTailer()

      • indexForId

        @NotNull
public @NotNull net.openhft.chronicle.core.values.LongValue indexForId(@NotNull
                                                                                @NotNull String id)

      • createTailer

        @NotNull
public @NotNull ExcerptTailer createTailer()
        Description copied from interface: ChronicleQueue
        Creates and returns a new ExcerptTailer for this ChronicleQueue. A Tailer is NOT thread-safe. A Tailer can be created by one Thread and might be used by at most one other Thread.. Sharing a Tailer across threads is unsafe and will inevitably lead to errors and unspecified behaviour.

        The tailor is created at the start, so unless you are using named tailors, this method is the same as calling `net.openhft.chronicle.queue.ChronicleQueue#createTailer(java.lang.String).toStart()`

        Specified by:
        createTailer in interface ChronicleQueue
        Returns:
        a new ExcerptTailer to read sequentially.
        See Also:
        ChronicleQueue.createTailer(String)

        Parameters:

        createIfAbsent - create missing stores if true, or return null if missing

        public int nextCycle(int cycle,
                     @NotNull
                     @NotNull TailerDirection direction)
              throws ParseException
        Description copied from interface: RollingChronicleQueue
        the next available cycle, no cycle will be created by this method, this method is typically used by a tailer to jump to the next cycle when the cycles are not adjacent.
        Specified by:

        Parameters:

        direction - the direction

      • countExcerpts

        public long countExcerpts(long fromIndex,
                          long toIndex)
        Will give you the number of excerpts between 2 index?s ( as exists on the current file system ). If intermediate chronicle files are removed this will effect the result.
        Specified by:
        countExcerpts in interface RollingChronicleQueue
        Parameters:
        fromIndex - the lower index
        toIndex - the higher index
        Returns:
        will give you the number of excerpts between 2 index?s. It?s not as simple as just subtracting one number from the other.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if we are not able to read the chronicle files

      • lastIndex

        public long lastIndex()
        Description copied from interface: ChronicleQueue
        Returns the index of the last non-metadata excerpt written to this ChronicleQueue, or -1 if the queue is empty.

        The value returned by this method will not be reliable in the event the queue is being written to concurrently, as subsequent excerpts may have been written by the time it is returned.

        Specified by:
        lastIndex in interface ChronicleQueue
        Returns:
        The highest non-metadata index available for this ChronicleQueue, or -1 if the queue is empty
